Cache.summary: The Cache interface provides a persistent storage mechanism for / object pairs that are cached in long lived memory. How long a Cache object lives is browser dependent, but a single origin's scripts can typically rely on the presence of a previously populated Cache object. Note that the Cache interface is exposed to windowed scopes as well as workers. You don't have to use it in conjunction with service workers, even though it is defined in the service worker spec.

remarks.para: An origin can have multiple, named Cache objects. You are responsible for implementing how your script (e.g., in a ) handles Cache updates. Items in a Cache do not get updated unless explicitly requested; they don't expire unless deleted. Use to open a specific named Cache object and then call any of the Cache methods to maintain the Cache.

You are also responsible for periodically purging cache entries. Each browser has a hard limit on the amount of cache storage that a given origin can use. Cache quota usage estimates are available via the method. The browser does its best to manage disk space, but it may delete the Cache storage for an origin. The browser will generally delete all of the data for an origin or none of the data for an origin. Make sure to version caches by name and use the caches only from the version of the script that they can safely operate on. See Deleting old caches for more information.

blockquote.para: The key matching algorithm depends on the VARY header in the value. So matching a new key requires looking at both key and value for entries in the Cache object.
The caching API doesn't honor HTTP caching headers.

remarks.para:
-Using Service Workers
-Service workers basic code example
-Using web workers

CacheAdd.summary: The add() method of the interface takes a URL, retrieves it, and adds the resulting response object to the given cache.

remarks.para: The add() method is functionally equivalent to the following:
For more complex operations, you'll need to use directly.

blockquote.para: add() will overwrite any key/value pair previously stored in the cache that matches the request.

CacheAddAll.summary: The addAll() method of the interface takes an array of URLs, retrieves them, and adds the resulting response objects to the given cache. The request objects created during retrieval become keys to the stored response operations.

blockquote.para:
addAll() will overwrite any key/value pairs
previously stored in the cache that match the request, but will fail if a
resulting put() operation would overwrite a previous cache entry stored by the same addAll() method.

CacheDelete.summary:
The delete() method of the interface finds the entry whose key is the request, and if found, deletes the entry and returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to true.
If no entry is found, it resolves to false.
CacheDelete.returns:
A that resolves to true if the cache entry is
deleted, or false otherwise.

CacheKeys.summary:
The keys() method of the interface returns a
{{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to an array of objects
representing the keys of the .

remarks.para: The requests are returned in the same order that they were inserted.

blockquote.para:
Requests with duplicate URLs but different headers can be
returned if their responses have the VARY header set on them.

CacheKeys.returns:
A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to an array of
objects.

CacheMatch.summary:
The match() method of the interface returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to the associated with the first matching request in the object.
If no match is found, the resolves to .
CacheMatch.returns:
A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to the first that matches
the request or to if no match is found.
NOTECache.match() is basically identical to
, except that rather than resolving with an array of
all matching responses, it resolves with the first matching response only (that is,
response[0]).

CacheMatchAll.summary:
The matchAll() method of the
interface returns a that resolves to an array of all matching
responses in the object.
CacheMatchAll.returns:
A that resolves to an array of all matching responses in the
object.
NOTE is basically identical to
Cache.matchAll(), except that rather than resolving with an array of all
matching responses, it resolves with the first matching response only (that is,
response[0]).

CachePut.summary:
The put() method of the
interface allows key/value pairs to be added to the current
object.

remarks.para:
Often, you will just want to
one or more requests, then add the result straight to your cache. In such cases you are
better off using
/, as
they are shorthand functions for one or more of these operations.

blockquote.para:
put() will overwrite any key/value pair
previously stored in the cache that matches the request.

/ do not
cache responses with Response.status values that are not in the 200
range, whereas Cache.put lets you store any request/response pair. As a
result, / can't be used to store
opaque responses, whereas Cache.put can.
